ai-mn74:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
ai-mn74:2.1_0: Then the wanderer Dīghanakha went up to the Buddha,
ai-mn74:2.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side.
ai-mn74:2.2_1: He bowed, stood to one side, and said to the Buddha,
ai-mn74:2.3_0: “Master Gotama, this is my doctrine and view:
ai-mn74:2.7_0: “If I believed in this view, Master Gotama, it wouldn’t make any difference, it wouldn’t make any difference!”
ai-mn74:3.1_0: “There are many more in the world who say:
ai-mn74:3.2_0: ‘That is such a thing! The difference!’
ai-mn74:3.3_0: But they don’t give up that view, and they grasp another view.
ai-mn74:3.4_0: And there are a scant few in the world who say,
ai-mn74:3.5_0: ‘That is such a thing! The difference!’
ai-mn74:3.6_0: And they give up that view by not grasping another view.
ai-mn74:4.1_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

ai-mn74:4.5_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
ai-mn74:4.6_0: believe in some things and not in others.
ai-mn74:4.7_0: Regarding this, the view of the ascetics and brahmins who believe in everything
ai-mn74:4.8_0: is close to greed, bondage, approving, attachment, and grasping.
ai-mn74:4.9_0: The view of the ascetics and brahmins who believe in nothing
ai-mn74:4.10_0: is far from greed, bondage, approving, attachment, and grasping.”
ai-mn74:5.1_0: When he said this, the wanderer Dīghanakha said to the Buddha,
ai-mn74:5.2_0: “Master Gotama commends my conviction! He recommends my conviction!”
ai-mn74:5.3_0: “Now, regarding the ascetics and brahmins who
ai-mn74:5.4_0: believe in some things and not in others.
ai-mn74:5.5_0: Their view of what they believe in is close to greed, bondage, approving, attachment, and grasping.
ai-mn74:5.6_0: Their view of what they don’t believe in is far from greed, bondage, approving, attachment, and grasping.

ai-mn74:6.9_0: an ascetic or brahmin who believes in nothing,
ai-mn74:6.10_0: and an ascetic or brahmin who believes in some things and not in others.
ai-mn74:6.11_0: These are the two in which this use.
ai-mn74:6.12_0: And so there is a dispute, mindfulness, and a dispute that might arise.

ai-mn74:9.1_0: Aggivessana, this body is physical. It’s made up of the four primary elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction. You should see it as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
ai-mn74:9.2_0: Doing so, you’ll give up desire, affection, and subservience to the body.
ai-mn74:10.3_0: At a time when you feel a pleasant feeling, you don’t feel a painful or neutral feeling;
ai-mn74:10.4_0: At that time they feel a pleasant feeling.
ai-mn74:10.5_0: At a time when you feel a painful feeling, you don’t feel a pleasant or neutral feeling;
ai-mn74:10.6_0: At that time they feel a painful feeling,
ai-mn74:10.7_0: At a time when you feel a neutral feeling, you don’t feel a pleasant or painful feeling;
ai-mn74:10.8_0: At that time they feel a neutral feeling.
ai-mn74:11.1_0: Pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.
ai-mn74:11.2_0: Painful feelings, painful feelings, and neutral feelings are all impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.
ai-mn74:11.3_0: Neutral feeling, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.
ai-mn74:12.1_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.
ai-mn74:12.2_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-mn74:12.3_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-mn74:13.1_0: A mendicant whose mind is freed like this doesn’t side with anyone or fight with anyone. They speak the language of the world without misapprehending it.”
ai-mn74:14.1_0: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was standing behind the Buddha fanning him.
ai-mn74:14.3_0: “It seems the Buddha speaks of giving up and letting go all these things through direct knowledge.”
ai-mn74:14.4_0: Reflecting like this, Venerable Sāriputta’s mind was freed from the defilements by not grasping.
ai-mn74:15.1_0: And the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in the wanderer Dīghanakha:
ai-mn74:15.2_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-mn74:15.3_0: Then Dīghanakha saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He said to the Buddha:
ai-mn74:16.2_0: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
ai-mn74:16.2_1: those with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-mn74:16.2_2: just so have you made the Teaching clear in many ways.
ai-mn74:16.3_0: Good Gotama, I go for refuge to you, and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
ai-mn74:16.4_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-mn74:16.5_0: The fourth section on Dīghanakha is finished.
